subtitle: [Music]
Thinking Allowed.
Conversations on the leading edge of knowledge
and discovery with psychologist Jeffrey Mishlove.
Hello and welcome. I'm Jeffrey Mishlove.
Today we'll be exploring the topic of remote
viewing the afterlife. My guest is Daz Smith, a full-time professional remote
viewer. He is also the editor and publisher of Eight Martinis, a magazine
of remote viewing. He is the author of a number of books including Surfing the
Psychic Internet, Remote Viewing Dialogues, CRV:
Controlled Remote Viewing, and Remote Viewing 9/11.
Daz is based in England. Now, I'll switch over to the internet video.
Welcome, Daz it's a real pleasure once again to be
with you. Yes, nice to be with you again and thanks
for having me back. We've gotten a very
positive response to the first video that we did
on Ingo Swann's fascinating work remote viewing the moon and
other locations. As a matter of fact, what I'm
going to do is link to that video now in case some
of our viewers haven't watched it. If you don't have a cell phone
there's a hot link right above where my finger
is and you can watch that video right now if you
like before we begin our conversation today, which is equally fascinating:
remote viewing the afterlife. I guess to set the stage we should talk a little
bit about the fact that this is one of a series of
remote viewing projects you did with Courtney Brown and
the Farsight Institute. I think I worked 16
targets over a period of probably eight years with
Courtney. This was target 14 and we never knew what
we were doing. Literally the only identification I
had to go on was, this is target 14. That's what myself and the other remote
viewers used as our queue in this. It was a great project. We did it in
2015 and we put out the video that you've seen in 2016.
That was video material Courtney essentially
cut out of the production and it ended up on
the cutting room floor. But we felt it was so interesting
that we thought people would like to see someone that
actually RV’d someone going through the afterlife kind of
experienced. To set the stage a little more, Courtney had
established the target to which you were blind of the assassination of John F.
Kennedy in Dealey Plaza in Dallas, Texas, in November 1963.
The target itself… I think it had two separate
targets within the encoding of it at Courtney's end
. I think one part was to look at the assassination itself and one part,
because he wanted to find out who was involved, was to get us to try to find
out who the conspirators were, if there was a
conspiracy, and try to follow them as well. So yeah, it
had a two-part project. It's very interesting. I know
Courtney has put out a number of videos looking at mysterious targets of this
sort. I know in our last conversation about Ingo Swann and his work looking at
phenomenon going on in outer space, Ingo made a point and you agreed with him,
that if you're not getting feedback so that you can compare your transcript
with some physical event, it's not really a full formal remote
viewing according to the classical protocol. Yes, that's correct. We're
lucky in this case in that we did the target
blind, we didn't know we were looking at the JFK
assassination. We do have quite a lot of feedback
material. We have all the documentation, all the
news reports, the Zapruder film for example.
If I report details that aren't in any of those media sources then it gets
a little bit hazy on whether that's valid data
or not. But the fact of the matter is, and this
should be of great interest to our viewers, there were
many points in which your descriptions were right on.
Absolutely, yes. It's probably one of my best RV sessions and it might be because
I've always had a lifelong interest in the Kennedy
assassination. I’ve read several books on it and watched
the Oliver Stone film on it as well, which is a
classic. I think that helped. I had some great
data points on it, only some things can't be confirmed.
I did detail shots coming from several different
directions, which as you know is a controversial point at this stage.
But you were able to identify, while blind to the actual target I want to
keep emphasizing that, that you were viewing an individual who was a
passenger in a vehicle who had been suddenly
attacked and killed. Absolutely, yes. In CRV, or remote viewing the way we do it,
we're not allowed to name things, so I don't actually say
in the session, “This is a person that's being shot.” I
mentioned that it’s a person in a vehicle that's having an event where two
sources of movement and energy are moving towards
him. I'm trying not to say that these are bullets. But
essentially, I am describing bullets and an
assassination, yes. The part that we are going to focus
in on now is what you experienced in your remote viewing at the moment of
death and shortly thereafter. I have to be honest. It
was probably my most life-changing RV session I've done
in 24 years. I go through the RV session in the video because all this was
captured live on video. We didn't really go through this
much on paper. But live on video I went with the flow of
the experience I was having and I felt like it was a
person having their death experience. So I thought, let's
see where this goes. I had no aim behind it at
all. It was just pure accident. It was really
interesting because I knew the life form at the time
of the event was having… They were going through
this travel event where he was having an
interaction with energy. I kind of knew it was
bullets but I didn't want to say the word bullets. I knew
that there was some distress there and I could feel the
distress and the emotional turmoil he was going
through, all these questions. It was amazing. It was a
process where you flip a light switch and there was a silence and
a mindfulness instantaneously where the panic of all those questions and
what will my wife do or my kids, all that kind of
stuff, instantly fell away into this just most beautiful
sense of mindfulness. From that point on I experienced these very small particles
of light form essentially out of nowhere into very blurry but human type forms.
They also interacted and kind of guided, I guess JFK,
as he was going through this amazing process. In the
video you never identified him as JFK but by the time you had described a
passenger in a car obviously being killed
suddenly and unexpectedly, you also mentioned that
you knew this event happened in the past but that it still is affecting people,
that many people are emotionally attached to this particular event long
after or at least some period of time after it had happened.
It wouldn't have been too hard to surmise that it might
be the Kennedy assassination. Absolutely. In my mind—because
you do start to build up a picture of the target in your
own head when you're doing this kind of work—in my mind I
do remember thinking, well, I know it's a life form in a car. I felt it was male,
but sometimes you get male and female wrong so I
didn't go on that data. But I knew it was a life
form in a car going through a death event
situation that had a great impact on society.
I could only think of three of those. The one
that started World War II, the Ferdinand one,
JFK one and maybe even, a bit of a stretch, but the possible Diana
Princess of Wales crash event. I think there
were only three scenarios that it could
possibly be but because of the feeling and the drawings I did,
the sketch of the vehicle as it went around a
certain corner and there was a hill, a grassy area
and the energy motions that were coming from different
directions. I kind of had more of a feeling at that point that it
was the JFK assassination. But you never
said that and I guess that's because of your
discipline. That's correct, yes. If it came really strong
in my mind and I knew it was going to interrupt
and bring a lot of noise to the RV session I
would have actually objectified that on the sheet
of paper or on the whiteboard. But I felt I was just
keeping my mind open to it at this stage. I didn't actually name anything like
bullets or anything like that. I allowed myself
to just go with the flow and not be influenced
too much by other things. The afterlife experience that you had.
How long did it actually last? On camera it looks like it's
probably about five to ten minutes. So quite in depth. The interesting thing
is that if people get to see the video on this, it's online in several places,
it's quite emotional for me as well at the same
time. Again, it was completely unexpected. I had
no plan to do this. There was no planning
Courtney's targeting of us getting the information,
for me to go off on essentially a tangent and get this information. I had no
preconceived ideas of life after death. I had trained in the past in mediumship
but because of my training in remote viewing and
being able to get any kind of information I want
using those sources, I have to be honest at
the time of doing this RV session I was a bit,
what's the right word, I didn't really fully
believe in the life after death process.
But this experience and feeling the
calmness and the process that this life went
through, that definitely changed my mind and
weighted it a bit more in the direction of some kind of life after death existence.
For viewers who haven't seen that video I will link to it now on
YouTube. It's available. If you don't have a cell phone,
if you're using a regular computer, you can hotlink right
above where my finger is and watch the video. It was made by
Dick Algier and you and Courtney Brown all together.
It's a fascinating video. One of the things that intrigues me about this
video that you've just explained to me is that when you
worked with Courtney on this project you actually worked on it
for months putting your
remote viewing impressions on paper and pen or pencil
before you did it in front of the video cameras and on the whiteboard.
When you visited the afterlife did that take place prior to the actual video?
No. I would have to go through the RV session, bearing
in mind it's like seven years ago, but I don't recall
doing anything on paper other than maybe recording that I felt
like there may be a death involved somewhere at the target
in general. The amazing thing with remote viewing,
what happens is, and this is a process I
think has only come about the last few years,
is that when we do things live on the whiteboard,
because we're standing up and we're using our entire body,
our fingers, our hands, we're moving around, I think it
kind of initiates a kinesthetic process where
the whole body gets involved in the RV instead of
normal RV. In normal RV I would be sat at a desk so half my body's not being used.
But because you're in full flow in front of a
white board and your whole body's being used
I feel that that dramatically increased my capability
and my sensitivities that I was going for in the
process and it allowed me to capture much
more detail in real time as it was occurring.
It's a funny word, remote viewing. It certainly implies that it's mostly based
on visual sensitivity but obviously your awareness of
non-physical reality and also your awareness that a death was
involved must have been some other form of knowing, not strictly visual.
Yes. For myself it's hardly ever visual. Remote viewing is
a terrible word for the experience, really. I would say for me
two to three percent of it is visual. If it is
visual in my head it literally is a black and white
image that's there for a fleeting second. A bit like when
you look at something and then you look away and you get an
after image. That's how the visualization is. Where this information comes from I
still do not know. For me personally, everything is just an internal
subtle feeling that I just have to transcribe from feeling into
words and pictures as best I can. Of course, when you're describing
something taking place—I'll call it in hyperspace but not in our normal
three-dimensional reality—it's very hard to put into words of any kind.
It is, yes. Especially this one with the death process.
I felt the calmness and I can't
even put it into words even now. Even now it lingers in my own head, the calmness at
this state that I felt in RV. It was literally so much noise and so much
emotional, almost like screaming from this life
form, you could feel it at the stage of death. Then
literally, like an instant light switch, it's the shock of
that noise and then no noise, and then complete calmness which
today pervades me. It eludes me. It's something that
I probably yearn to get back to in some sense because I've never
experienced such calmness like that in my life really. It seemed as if
Kennedy, I presume you were viewing Kennedy, also achieved a sort of egoless
state where, yes, his emotions, his attachments to his present role on the
physical plane was still there but at the same time he was distant. It didn't
have the same grip on him. Absolutely. At the point of the event happening and all
the motion and energy hitting him, for a split second,
all that screaming out, I could hear his thoughts. “Oh
my god, what about my kids, what about my wife, why'd
this happen?” Then with that light switch effect it was
like all that was stripped away and it just did not matter anymore.
I felt that although I was feeling the mindfulness, he
must have been actually going through that
transformation process. It felt like stages. It felt
like the whole event also transcended time.
What would be like a minute split second event
for me felt like five to ten minutes as I was
going through it. It was timeless, or time
slowed down. It was very interesting to see after that light switch effect how,
I would say, time didn't exist anymore after
that. So it was mindfulness and time didn't exist.
I felt he went through several states of
transformation at that split second of time.
One of those states I suppose is just a question of orienting to this very
different reality. Yes, I would have thought
so. I didn't see anything visually. It was all
feelings for me. You're going from a physical state where you have everything
inputting into you… What I did feel is, it did feel like a
huge pink openness of space.
It does have some kind of physicality in that it
did feel kind of smokey and misty but that felt
more like energy that was like a mist or a smokiness. But
it was everywhere and you were part of that, everything
at the same time. As I said, it's very hard for me to put
all this into words really. I got the impression
watching your description of it on the video that
the smoky misty quality was in some sense alive,
that figures would sort of emerge from it
and they were part of it and that these were
other beings who had come to greet him. Absolutely, yes.
I remember that they weren't there in a true form that
just came out of nowhere out of the mist. They kind
of coalesced or transformed or emerged from out of this
mistiness, almost like particles of a fizzy kind of
particles of light that kind of sucked inwards and
then coalesced into these very loose human style
silhouette forms. What struck me is that, I didn't recall you saying it during the
portion of the video where you were describing
the remote viewing process, but afterwards
in reflecting on what you had experienced you suggested
that the person, Kennedy, was communicating, I
think was the word you used. After he got over it,
as the light switch moment happened, I would say a split second of what's
happening to me, the loss of the ego, the loss
of the self in some kind of regard there. Then
as sparkles coalesced into these forms I felt
that he knew who they were instantly and there
definitely was a communication and a greeting kind of
experience, a welcoming kind of experience going on there. There was a great
feeling of love and enjoyment and calmness about the whole thing.
Did it go much beyond that? I don't think I followed it any further to be
honest. I think at that stage, not long after there, I
think I probably pulled back from it and didn't didn't go
any further. As I said, the whole experience
wasn't really part of what the project was
about. It was me going off on a tangent really.
I was a little bit aware that maybe I was
describing something that the target person
didn't want so my discipline kind of pulled me
out a little bit at that stage. Or maybe even a bit of fear or reluctance on my part
to go any further. You mentioned that you had
also had training, I suppose prior to the remote
viewing training, as a medium. Yes, many years ago before I
did remote viewing training. I started early. I was quite lucky in
that I grew up in a household where my mother
was a psychic clairvoyant medium. She also
ran the local spiritualist church. So from the
age of six on up we went to the spiritual church.
On a Sunday I would watch mediums give
talks about people that they were seeing and
stuff. So I trained there from the age of 16 onwards. I did mediumship and
clairvoyance and channeling and lots of other
things. But as I said, I kind of stopped doing
all that when I found remote viewing because I found
all that kind of stuff was a bit chaotic in that
I was a passenger in the process and the
process was driving the car so I had no control.
What I found with remote viewing was that it
allowed me to take control and be the driver of the
car and stop the process when I want to investigate and all
that kind of stuff. So, yeah, I did have training in it but
I kind of lost my way with the classical techniques
and ended up with remote viewing. At this point in
your life, what is your attitude toward the prospects of
survival of consciousness after death?
It's hard. I think it changes day to day. Some days I'm absolutely convinced.
When I review the video of my experiences of the JFK
assassination event I'm even more convinced. I should go back and rewatch it
on a periodic basis to remind myself because
I think I forget. Sometimes I'm a bit
worried about, can I get the same kind of data
through RV? I'm not so convinced in that now.
I think RV is taking me down a different path where it's
showing me that the universe around us is a lot more
conscious than we realize. So yes, I'm still open-minded.
I can't say I'm an absolute 100 percent convert of life after death
but I do believe there's something there happening. It
makes sense otherwise everything would be just such a waste
really and the universe doesn't work like that. It sounds to me like
what you're suggesting is that the universe
is so complex that our attempts to express it
in the English language, a phrase like life after
death, doesn't really capture the nuances of it.
Yes, that's so clear. It is so complex. It's like a
multi-layered onion. There's so many different things going on. The interesting
thing about the life after death experience that
I had is that it's not that much different from
when we had these experiences when we communicate
or go to a UFO/ET type craft or somewhere off
planet, or even something else with remote viewing. It seems like everything is
interconnected in the universe: love, chi energy, consciousness.
I think we fumble for words to describe
what's going on. I do believe though that there's… It seems to indicate to me, and it
seems to be growing in my appreciation of this, that there seems to be some kind of
conscious kind of decision making
intelligence behind it all. I don't want to put a word
on it like god because I don't know what I believe in
that sense but there does feel like there's a higher being
kind of consciousness that seems to be driving all
this and helping us through it at some level. Have
you made any other efforts to go back with remote viewing and look again at the
afterlife? I would love to. The only problem
we have as remote viewers is we rely on
people setting us the targets to do that because
we have to work totally blind. It's like one of
these big projects that it's in a pool that I would
absolutely love to do if someone wanted to set it to me as a
project but no one has yet. What about other remote viewers? I know
you're very much in touch with the community of people engaged in this work.
Have there been other reports of remote viewing visits to the afterlife?
Not many, to be honest. I think I've read a
few when people have done missing people cases.
Sometimes you're looking at a person that's
deceased so you get a little bit of crossover event
happening there. But in the 24 years I've been
looking at this I don't think I've seen any
proper interested kind of projects to really
look at this with remote viewing. I think it's something that’s
sorely missed actually. There's something that we could do if we could
get a few people together and a good project manager on it.
Absolutely. I know Raymond Moody has written a book based
on his earlier research on the near-death experience that oftentimes
people who are in a death bed hospital room, for example,
at the moment of death have the experience of just sort
of going along into the afterlife, at least the early
stages of it with the departed. Spontaneously.
Absolutely. I'm lucky enough to have been present at
the passing of several of my relatives, including my parents.
Being a sensitive person I would say that I can definitely feel
that there is some kind of level of contentment that they reach at a stage
a few moments before there is this kind of passing
event. It does feel like there is an energy transfer of
some kind. I can't say I've physically seen it
or anything. Just like we're doing the remote
viewing, I just feel or sense an energy transfer with some kind of release which
is interesting on its own, I think. Maybe that's
an area that could also be looked at by science. In
other words, it would be possible to establish an ongoing remote viewing
program that could probe these non-physical realms in a rather
systematic precise manner. Absolutely. I think
it would be a fantastic use of the tool of
remote viewing. I'm sure we could go further than I went
and maybe see where it goes from there because I'm at a loss of what
happens after that meeting event of meeting your past friends and family.
The only slight thing we would have would be
verifying it with potential feedback, but I think we
have enough anecdotal stories from people
that have also gone down that route to give us
some level of feedback on that, to give us some idea. Certainly from our previous
interview I know you feel that remote viewing information is best used in
conjunction with other sources and not simply all by itself.
Absolutely. You always need to use it with other
sources of information. That's why remote viewing was
essentially built and established and used by the US and the
Russian military units. They had insufficient data and they
wanted another source to add to it to verify that data.
It was never really used alone and I don't think it should
be today. We can slightly rely on the track record of a viewer. For
example, over many years now I've had a database
accuracy record that people can look back on and say,
okay, he's usually this accurate so there's no reason
he should be completely off on this target. But
feedback is most definitely part of the equation
that you need. Absolutely. I'd like to go back
to our earlier interview whne we talked about
Ingo Swann's visits to the moon and elsewhere
using remote viewing. I bring it up because I know that if one digs into the
literature on seances and mediumship and also ufology there seems to be a certain
amount of overlap that people report encounters with
non-human beings, potentially alien beings, and the departed sometimes occur
in the same setting. Absolutely. It's
across the board as well. I've worked on many
projects with many of the top people in remote viewing
and even when you get what I call a newbie or a new person
practicing remote viewing, when you're getting them
past a certain level that they can start to handle
what I would call mystery or esoteric type targets, if
you give them a target like the moon or Mars or something,
undoubtedly every single time they… I don't think
they're being influenced by me as a tasker, but
every single time, whoever the tasker is, they talk about
seeing structures and past life forms on Mars and the moon.
When we do missing people cases as well—because I've done 250 of these myself
for the United States police forces—when they're deceased then as well
as a remote viewer you can get information from
a deceased person, so there seems to be some very
strange continuation of this energy and information. Maybe it's the same
thing. Maybe the energy is information or the information
is energy and it seems to be everywhere within us. I
don't think I'm going anywhere. I don't think I go to Mars
or go to a dead person to get information. I think that
information is already within me, I'm just
tapping into it. That makes perfect sense when
one thinks of consciousness as being the ground of being
itself, that who we are is much larger than just this body.
Absolutely, yes. I think some of the Eastern philosophies have it right as well.
I'm lucky enough in my past, and not so much now because I've
been ill the last year, to have done quite a lot of martial
arts. I found that the when I was practicing tai chi and qigong
that made a real lot of sense to me. I think
that also massively enhanced what I'm capable of
doing in remote viewing because even then I felt the chi
energy that I felt flowing through the ground and flowing
through me, it felt to be the same creative force that I was getting through remote
viewing, and just through my normal creative process. It seems to have the same
essence, the kind of energy that I experienced
when I saw the pink kind of fluffy things that
coalesced into forms that JFK conversed
with. It all seems to be a continuous flow of
energy and information at some level. Daz, I'm really glad that we've connected.
This has been a very pleasurable conversation. I hope that you and I can
have many more to share with the New Thinking Allowed
audience. I know that our previous video was very popular and
our viewers are asking me to bring you back often. Yeah, that would be fantastic.
Maybe we can talk in the future about some of the remote viewing
we're doing at the moment predicting markets. That's going very
well as well, financials. That's a big interest of mine
so I would be very happy to discuss that with you. Great.
It's been an honor chatting to you these two
times. Thank you so much for being with me Daz.
It's been a pleasure thank you. And for those of you
watching or listening, thank you for being with us.
[Music]
